reviewText:
Timberman is a very simple, yet addicting game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=erDSD1M5MOo
This is a port of a mobile game, although it totally works fine on the PC.
There are only two controls, cut left, or cut right. Which means that both controller or keyboard controls are sufficient.

Your objective is to cut the tree as much as you can without dying. On both sides of the tree, there are branches. If you cut the tree from the left side, and a branch falls onto your head, you lose. So instead, you switch to the other side to cut from the right. It's a very simplistic idea, but can have you constantly trying to top your previous score.

As you play the game, you'll unlock new characters to use. They don't play different, it's purely cosmetic.

You can also play local or online multiplayer. You win a round by either cutting your tree a lot faster than your opponent, which causes your side of the bar to reach their side, or if they simply mess up and die from a branch.

Overall, it's an incredibly cheap game, with added multiplayer and characters over its mobile version. Simple, yet very addicting.

reviewText:
Introduction
Here‚Äôs the premise: a team of time-travelling lumberjacks have reached Gaia, the immortal tree mother and have to chop at her as fast as possible, lest she grow too tall and cover the sun itself. With meteorite axes fused in the heart of the sun, each swipe of Gaia removes another chunk from her life-force. They are more than lumberjacks, they‚Äôre the saviours of earth itself.

Now, all of that was made up but it sounds about right. There is no story to Timberman, just the swing of an axe and the hope of a high score.
_________________________________

Gameplay
In Timberman, you tap either left or right on your arrow keys to chop at a presumably infinite tree trunk. Chop at either side, but do your best to avoid incoming branches. One hit of these, and it‚Äôs game over. Each chop lowers the tree, as well as a branch. There‚Äôs a greedy timer as well that runs on the top of the screen, and is refilled with each chop of the tree.

To sum it up, if you‚Äôve played Flappy Bird, Trip Runner or any one of the billions of infinite running games, you‚Äôll love Timberman. It‚Äôs just newer, faster and has better controls. Also, the chop-chop-chopping rhythm of the axe is hypnotically soothing.

There's also multiplayer in the form of either local splitscreen or a random online player you get matched up with.

Graphics
Take heed. Timberman‚Äôs a retro game so at this point in the review, you either hate it instantly or love it dearly. The barrage of cutesy 8-bit games are fun, but have begun to wear thin. I‚Äôm no game developer, but isn‚Äôt it more satisfying to simply have clean, sharp graphics instead of a pixelated mess? I like the graphics, and the gameplay is undemanding enough to warrant Timberman‚Äôs pared-down aesthetic. I‚Äôve just grown weary of these 8-bit style games.

Conclusion
Timberman carefully balances frustration with necessity thanks to an incredibly simple control-scheme of either left or right to chop. Chop well enough, and unlock a barrage of cutesy Timbermen which thankfully have no effect on the gameplay.
_________________________________

Verdict        Chop trees, compete for the highest score, rinse and repeat. Great game, is it worth your dollar? Maybe.

reviewText:
This release is a mobile port from the extremely popular Timberman. On mobile it was free but it is it actually worth purchasing the game?

Timberman is an extremely basic game, but it is highly addictive and fun. All you have to do is chop on the left and right of the right avoiding the incoming branches. You have to try and get as high as possible and so get as high a score as possible. There is a system put into place to stop you going to slow also. A bar slowly runs down the slower you go but goes up if you chop really fast. If this bar reaches zero then you will loose.

The really reason to purchase this on steam instead of playing on mobile is the new multiplayer mode. It's a lot of fun. You could describe it as a kinda tug of war gamemode. It uses the deteriorating bar from the other mode but with a twist. You both use the same bar. So you have to try and go faster than the other person so you don't loose. This mode isn't on the mobile version and is steam exclusive.

PositivesAddictive gameplay- The gameplay may not be the most unique about, but it sure is fun.
Multiplayer mode- Insane fun tug of war style mode which isn't on mobile.
Leaderboards- It integrates steam leaderboards so you can compare your scores in each mode against friends.
Ranking system- Each user is given a rank and skill level based on how good they do.
Graphics- Beautiful pixel graphics style. Multiple different settings for levels that each look as great as the previous. Alive backgrounds with animations of clouds and birds to keep it looking real.
Character skins- New character skins can be unlocked by getting to certain highscores.NegativesMatchmaking- Matchmaking is sometimes good but is more often than not very slow. It sometimes takes a few tries to actually get into a game. Users aren't kicked when they don't ready up. A few bugs can sometimes leave you stuck on the matchmaking screen making you have to restart the game.
Keyboard control- No keyboard control in the menus. When your playing the actually game with the keyboard it would be much easier to keep using it rather than having to switch to mouse.
Bug- A bug left an extra character on my screen that was obstructing my view. I had to restart the game to get it to go.
Sounds- I wasn't a fan of any of the sounds or music. I found them to be annoying and not satisfying to go along with the gameplay. I turned them off almost immediately and put on my own music.
That's about it for timberman. There is very little content but your playtime will come from repeating the game to try and beat your highscore. I think the multiplayer mode is enough to consider a purchase if you already play the mobile version. For the price of only ¬£0.79 it is well worth it. But I do hope they update the game putting some other modes in it to have a bit of variety.

reviewText:
Timberman is a 16bit wood chopping mini-game in which you use the arrow keys to both chop take un-human, whopping chunks out of the tree in a single stroke and to dodge the trees deadly branches. It's like Stepmania, but with more beards and flannel - a simple concept that's deceptively addicting.

There's a nice selection of skins to unlock for your lumberjack via various achievements which are mostly, but not all, chopping related and a speed chopping multiplayer challenge with global rankings. The audio clip that plays each time you chop sort of grates on your ears but there's a handy check box in the options menu to disable it. While you're in there I'd suggest muting the music as well - there's not a lot of variety, and if you're like me you're going to be spending an embarassing amount of time climbing up the ranked ladder.

Pros -
+Addicting. It's mobile app-crack come to Steam =p
+Skill Numbers and Global Rank give you a sense of progression, despite repeating the same activaty a bajillion times.
+Variety of skins let's you change it up. Slightly.

Cons -
+The Audio. All of it. I just mute the game and fire up Windows Media Player.
+Addicting. There are so many better things you could be doing with your time, but you cannot escape the call of the Timberman.

Basically, for $.99 you can't go wrong here. If there's a competitive bone in your body you can easily spend a few hours in the multiplayer, taking care of your wood with a stranger ;)

WARNING: I DO NOT HATE THIS GAME, I AM A BIT DISAPPOINTED. I AM ONLY STATING HOW I FEEL. DO NOT HATE FOR NO REASON. Timberman Timberman is a game that has once started on mobile, now ported to Steam

The Game Itself
The game is a basic Concept.
The game is a game where you are a lumberjack or other kinds of people (I will get to get to that in a moment)

Gameplay
The Gameplay is simple yet enjoyful. To play the game you have to tap left and right to avoid branches that will kill you while choping down the tree to get a bigger higher score, as well as unlock some other types of cameo's that you can customize yourself with. You could be Jason, to a wrestler, to flappy bird itself. cool and funny but doesn't make any difference to the Gameplay other than appearance

There are 4 types of controls

- A+D
- Left and Right Arrows
- and the controller (LB+RB and Left and Right on the Dpad)

The Gameplay can also be addicting if you really want to put the effort into this game but your most likely not. In my experience I was bored with it within the first few day of purchasing this game.

Multiplayer
Another thing that makes this game pretty cool in my opinion from the mobile port and that is also exclusive to Steam is the Multiplayer Counter part. This may add 30 minutes to 1 hour of extra playtime. You play the usual mode like in single player but you could play against other people online or split screen. there is 2 player, 3 player, and 4 player. And the concept here is that it is the last man standing wins. best out of 3 standings is the true winner.

Overall The game in general is fun to play for the first and second day of purchasing the game, but in honesty unless you have friends that also own this game, can get addicted to games like these but on PC then I recommend you skip or maybe at most avoid this game.

reviewText:
Short review:
Simple gameplay using 3 buttons
Can be played with one hand
Relatively cheap
Can play as a variety of unexpectedly different characters
Supports online multiplayer as well as local multiplayerMore words:

This game is the most excellent time-killing game I've played. Easy to pick up and put down at a moments notice, I often find myself playing it when I'm waiting for something else, only to get immersed into it and just continue playing anyways.

The gameplay is simple: you use one of many provided button combinations (you can use a keyboard, mouse or controller) to chop either the left or right side of the tree. Keep chopping until a branch hits you (via chopping on the wrong side) or the timer at the top runs out from going too slow (which is a non-issue until your score gets really high).

The unlockable characters also give motivation to play, and  you can even play as Gaben.

The passive online mode is a nice touch; the game actively searches for multiplayer lobbies while you play single player. There's an option to turn this off as well should you only wish to play in singleplayer. If you want to play multiplayer only, there's an option for that too; the game will search for an open lobby, and if there isn't one, it'll automatically create a lobby for you.

My only complaint about the game is the music; the only song is a short chiptune song that speeds up in intensity the more you play, and resets after you die. It's catchy at first and the idea sounds good on paper, but I personally find it rather distracting and annoying after a while. Fortunately, you can turn off the music (and the sound effects if you want) in the options menu and just play your own music instead.

Overall, I think the game's simplicity is its strong suit, which is why it's priced as such. I'd say it's worth it if you find yourself wanting something to kill time while waiting for something else, or if you just have some spare change lying around and want a cheap and simple game, especially if it's on sale.

reviewText:
This is one of the most addictive, easy-to-play but hard to master games out there. Although I was not familiar with its predecessor on iOS (apparently that's where it came out first) I couldn't resist the great price, well polished (or Polished? - game devs are from Poland) experience and the appealing sense of simplicity. Seeing the controls help/options page at first was a bit confusing since every button is just CHOP - soon after I realized that the game is really that simple and each CHOP button has a direction (left or right).

Upon attempting to play with a keyboard, mouse and Xbox 360 controller I've settled on my mouse since it allows to click the fastest and it seemed I am already naturally used to LEFT and RIGHT click as two directions unlike keyboard buttons or controller buttons.

The gameplay is fun and although not many people seem to be indulging in the multiplayer component of it, you can still get some solid chopping in in single player mode.

Variety of unlockable skins/outfits/characters gives the game additional appeal and increases the desire to grind!

Highly recommended! Have fun and add me on Steam if you'd like to 1v1 :-)

reviewText:
For the cost (especially if you get it on sale) this game is worth at least trying. Before playing for the first time, I didn't really have an opinion formed even though it's really obvious Timberman is a mobile game. The pixel graphics are nice (at least to me) and the combination of cross-platform online play with fast-playing arcade action made my decision an easy one.

The gameplay itself is extremely simple. The character being controlled moves left and right avoiding branches as fast as possible while chopping logs from the tree. That's it. That's all there is to the gameplay. This description makes it all sound very boring but if you actually play it, Timberman is good for at least several hours of your time. The game offers both personal and online goals to play towards. In the single player mode, the objective is to chop as many logs as possible and improve your high score as your skill ramps. The multi-player mode has the same high scoring end but against other people online. This could be done one-on-one or against up to three other people. One of the more appealing side-goals as your high scores increase over time is that there are 37 playable characters to unlock. Although, one of the unlockable characters is bugged (Timber Hook) and will not unlock.

Being good at Timberman is difficult and demands many simultaneous skills and abilities. In order to reach the 2,000 logs chopped Gabe Newell character unlock and for the player to be in the top 500 ranking (or better), this game is surprisingly challenging. A blend of patience, precision, speed, quick reflexes, dexterity, hand-eye coordination and stamina are mandatory to succeed. It's really fun to see your progress through the ranks over time and to beat higher ranking online opponents. With that said, there comes a time Timberman just starts being boring and the excitement and fun of competitive online ranked play stops driving you. The challenging and fast-paced gameplay stops being interesting and you'll feel like moving on to the next game on your list. The game is fun while it lasts. It just doesn't last very long.

Timberman is okay.

reviewText:
When I first bought this game, I was bored out of my mind and figured I could blow less than a dollar on a button masher type game. I didn't think I would play it much, but here I am 90 minutes later.

The basic premise of the game is simple- chop as many blocks off a tree and avoid getting hit by branches while going fast enough to maintain the game timer. If you get hit by a branch or go too slow, it's game over. You move back and forth on the tree by pressing left/right, or a/d or whatever you prefer.

There are 40 characters to unlock through various game goals. Some of the ways to unlock characters revolves around hitting a certain number of tree blocks in one life, or reaching a certain lifetime number of chops. It gives the game some replay value.

Moving on to multiplayer, it's just as simple as single player. You can play two people on one computer, or take it to the internet to battle anyone else looking for a match. I played a variety of matches, and it's basically a best out of 5 match. If you're evenly matched, one battle can take a good minute or more. Most are shorter than that. But if you're too slow (get behind by around 20 chops), you also lose that way too. It's fun, and I liked the competition aspect of multiplayer. You can see each player's rank and skill, which makes it more fun when you beat people ranked higher than you.

Overall, I was surprised how much I was involved in the game. I will probably stick with it for awhile and it was worth it for the price.

Do you think trees are the bane of our existence?  Ever wanted to clear a whole forest by yourself?  If you answered yes either of these questions Timberman is the game for you!  Its a super straight-forward, silly game.  One that clearly was designed as a mobile game but had enough charm and appeal to sneak onto steam.

The goal is simple, cut down as much of these infinitely tall trees as possible.  You can cut from the left or right sides of the tree.  You'll need to move back a forth between the two sides to avoid branches jutting out of the tree.  Chop and dodge quickly for you time is limited.   Every hit will restore some time but the as round progress it becomes harder to keep up.  When the time runs out of you get hit once, you dead!

Learning to find a rhythm is very important for efficient dodging.  Instead of pausing every time a branch comes down you'll already be ready to swiftly move to the side.  Memorizing the patterns of going back and forth, especially for the double hits, is essential for fast dodges.  The added pressure from seeing the timer begin to rapidly decrease certain doesn't help.

If improving your score isn't enough motivation in itself there are several unlockable characters.  Many can either be made available simply be setting a high-score or just by chopping some much wood over time.  Some characters offer a little more interesting challenges for playing multiplayer matches, earning a certain score consecutively, or chopping so much wood in a particular time frame.  The multiplayer isn't particularly exciting online but this is a hilarious game for split-screen, one that would probably do great at parties or competitive events.

Have you ever wanted to be a lumberjack? Now's your chance as indie studio Digital Melody has brought the iOS and Android tree chopping sensation Timberman to Steam.

http://youtube.com/watch?v=YHOkFAeVCpM

The premise is almost too simple: press the left arrow on the keyboard to chop left and press the right arrow to chop right. The only real goal is to avoid dying at the hands of branches as you chop to your heart's content.

There's something almost hypnotic about the fast-paced action as you feverishly press left or right, avoiding branches before they slam into your character's face.

The single-player will keep you occupied for short bursts with a goal of beating high scores. The real fun is had in the multiplayer. You can either play with a friend split screen on the same computer or with up to three other people online.

The offline mode is a tug-of-war that ends way too fast. If one player gets too far ahead of the other, it's game over for the laggard. Disappointingly, there is not an option to change how far ahead you have to be in order to win, which means that some matches can end in a matter of a couple seconds.

The online multiplayer is more interesting, allowing you to face off against strangers or with a friend that you invite to the game. This mode does not have a tug of war element. Instead, it emphasizes survival. The last person standing wins a round with three rounds needed to win a match.

If you enjoy the prospects of carpal tunnel syndrome, you'll love Timberman. Timberman's simplicity is not only found in the fast-paced gameplay but also in the graphics and sound, which features a single repeating music track. The game reminds me a lot of Flappy Bird and endless runners like Bit.Trip.

For only a buck you can have the game on Steam. The iOS and Android versions are free but an ad-free version will also cost you only a dollar. It may be worth it for at least a couple hours of mindless casual gameplay.

Have you ever wanted to be a lumberjack? Now's your chance as indie studio Digital Melody has brought the iOS and Android tree chopping sensation Timberman to Steam.

http://youtube.com/watch?v=YHOkFAeVCpM

The premise is almost too simple: press the left arrow on the keyboard to chop left and press the right arrow to chop right. The only real goal is to avoid dying at the hands of branches as you chop to your heart's content.

There's something almost hypnotic about the fast-paced action as you feverishly press left or right, avoiding branches before they slam into your character's face.

The single-player will keep you occupied for short bursts with a goal of beating high scores. The real fun is had in the multiplayer. You can either play with a friend split screen on the same computer or with up to three other people online.

The offline mode is a tug-of-war that ends way too fast. If one player gets too far ahead of the other, it's game over for the laggard. Disappointingly, there is not an option to change how far ahead you have to be in order to win, which means that some matches can end in a matter of a couple seconds.

The online multiplayer is more interesting, allowing you to face off against strangers or with a friend that you invite to the game. This mode does not have a tug of war element. Instead, it emphasizes survival. The last person standing wins a round with three rounds needed to win a match.

If you enjoy the prospects of carpal tunnel syndrome, you'll love Timberman. Timberman's simplicity is not only found in the fast-paced gameplay but also in the graphics and sound, which features a single repeating music track. The game reminds me a lot of Flappy Bird and endless runners like Bit.Trip.

For only a buck you can have the game on Steam. The iOS and Android versions are free but an ad-free version will also cost you only a dollar. It may be worth it for at least a couple hours of mindless casual gameplay.

reviewText: Reminds me of Flappy Bird...

Do you think trees are the bane of our existence?  Ever wanted to clear a whole forest by yourself?  If you answered yes either of these questions Timberman is the game for you!  Its a super straight-forward, silly game.  One that clearly was designed as a mobile game but had enough charm and appeal to sneak onto steam.

The goal is simple, cut down as much of these infinitely tall trees as possible.  You can cut from the left or right sides of the tree.  You'll need to move back a forth between the two sides to avoid branches jutting out of the tree.  Chop and dodge quickly for you time is limited.   Every hit will restore some time but the as round progress it becomes harder to keep up.  When the time runs out of you get hit once, you dead!

Learning to find a rhythm is very important for efficient dodging.  Instead of pausing every time a branch comes down you'll already be ready to swiftly move to the side.  Memorizing the patterns of going back and forth, especially for the double hits, is essential for fast dodges.  The added pressure from seeing the timer begin to rapidly decrease certain doesn't help.

If improving your score isn't enough motivation in itself there are several unlockable characters.  Many can either be made available simply be setting a high-score or just by chopping some much wood over time.  Some characters offer a little more interesting challenges for playing multiplayer matches, earning a certain score consecutively, or chopping so much wood in a particular time frame.  The multiplayer isn't particularly exciting online but this is a hilarious game for split-screen, one that would probably do great at parties or competitive events.

This game is stupid simple.  You only need two buttons and all you have to do is chop quickly and dodge branches.  Yet there is a little more life beneath the surface.  Training your reflexes takes time and slowly you'll learn to become faster and more precise.  Speed also plays into a cockiness factor.  Its not hard to go fast but the more you push yourself the more easily you'll fail.  As little as there is to this game I feel there is enough to get your worth out it.
